headline.main: A TEACHER TRAINS FOR OUTER SPACE

results.snippet: IT'S SUCH A QUANTUM leap from what my life has been like,'' Christa McAuliffe was saying. A frown shadowed her brow. It was the frown of recurring disbelief, not of worry. So much had happened since July, when she was chosen from 11,000...

byline.original: By John Noble Wilford; John Noble Wilford reports on science and space for The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: IT'S SUCH A QUANTUM leap from what my life has been like,'' Christa McAuliffe was saying. A frown shadowed her brow. It was the frown of recurring disbelief, not of worry. So much had happened since July, when she was chosen from 11,000 schoolteacher applicants to be the first ''private citizen'' to fly in space. There was the White House ceremony, the onslaught of reporters and television cameras, the hometown parade. Then came the exchange of her high-school classroom for the high-tech simulators at Houston's Johnson Space Center, and the moment she stood on the launching pad at Cape Canaveral and got a close look at the space shuttle Challenger, which is to carry her, a 37-year-old teacher from Concord, N.H., into orbit next month. ''It just didn't hit home that the rockets are going to go off and I'm going to be 200 miles up in space,'' the mother of two recalled. ''It still doesn't seem possible.'' Yet, by all accounts, Christa McAuliffe has handled the quantum leap with aplomb and delight. She had just experienced weightlessness: the KC-135 climbed to a crest and then went into a headlong plunge. There she was, walking on the ceiling, then floating in the cabin like Superman. The experience can be euphoric and sometimes nauseous, which is why the training plane is called the ''vomit comet.'' Her trainers said she came through like a fully fledged astronaut.

headline.main: TWICE-DELAYED MISSION IS SET FOR LIFTOFF TODAY

results.snippet: The countdown went smoothly today for another attempt to launch the space shuttle Columbia on a five-day mission devoted mainly to science. The launching was delayed twice last month.   The Columbia is scheduled to lift off Monday at 7:05 A.M....

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The countdown went smoothly today for another attempt to launch the space shuttle Columbia on a five-day mission devoted mainly to science. The launching was delayed twice last month. The Columbia is scheduled to lift off Monday at 7:05 A.M. Eastern standard time. It is the first mission in more than two years for the Columbia, which has undergone extensive refurbishing.

headline.main: SHUTTLE LAUNCHING DELAYED YET AGAIN BY MECHANICAL FAILURE

results.snippet: The shuttle Columbia's return to space after a two-year layoff was delayed again today, this time because of troubles with a valve in the oxygen lines leading to the shuttle's main engines.   Last month the launching was first delayed when ground...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The shuttle Columbia's return to space after a two-year layoff was delayed again today, this time because of troubles with a valve in the oxygen lines leading to the shuttle's main engines. Last month the launching was first delayed when ground crews fell behind schedule, and a second time when problems with a secondary rocket engine forced ground controllers to abort the countdown just 14 seconds before liftoff. Space agency officials rescheduled Columbia's liftoff for Tuesday at 7:05 A.M. Eastern standard time, barring further problems. According to Air Force meteorologists, Tuesday's forecast calls for clouds and a chance of rain.

headline.main: STUDIES BOLSTER LINK OF FOOD AND MIGRAINES

results.snippet: NEW research is lending credence to a long debated idea that food allergies may cause migraines in a majority rather than a minority of people who have the headaches.   Several studies conducted in the United States and England in the last five...

byline.original: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE

results.lead_paragraph: NEW research is lending credence to a long debated idea that food allergies may cause migraines in a majority rather than a minority of people who have the headaches. Several studies conducted in the United States and England in the last five years have shown that about 75 percent of migraine patients are allergic to five or more foods, while some patients are allergic to 20 or more foods. When the patients were placed on diets that eliminated or drastically reduced contact with such ''trigger'' foods, their migraine headaches stopped or became less frequent and severe. Despite the gathering evidence implicating food allergies, many specialists are not fully persuaded of their importance and say they are awaiting more data. Most physicians agree that headaches, including migraines, are a symptom and not a disease. That is, there are underlying mechanisms that give rise to the sensation of head pain. Migraines affect one side of the head with pain lasting from a few hours to more than a week. Between 10 million and 20 million Americans experience migraines.

headline.main: DISTANT BAD WEATHER DELAYS SPACE SHUTTLE LIFTOFF

results.snippet: The launching of the space shuttle Columbia was postponed again today, this time because of bad weather at emergency landing sites in Europe and Africa. Frustrated space officials said they would try again Thursday.   The postponement was the fifth...

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

results.lead_paragraph: The launching of the space shuttle Columbia was postponed again today, this time because of bad weather at emergency landing sites in Europe and Africa. Frustrated space officials said they would try again Thursday. The postponement was the fifth in three weeks for the Columbia, which was first set to lift off Dec. 18, but it was the first delay in shuttle history that was caused by storms so distant, rain in Spain and dust in the Sahara.

headline.main: DEPT. FO SEXISM, BUREAU OF SO-WHAT

results.snippet: Grant P. Thompson became an instant celebrity this week.   Just when Americans had perhaps grown jaded by ''first woman'' events, from the first woman to become an astronaut to the first woman to become the Vice-Presidential nominee of a major...

byline.original: By ROBIN TONER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Grant P. Thompson became an instant celebrity this week. Just when Americans had perhaps grown jaded by ''first woman'' events, from the first woman to become an astronaut to the first woman to become the Vice-Presidential nominee of a major political party, Mr. Thompson created a new genre. It was announced that the 45-year-old Washingtonian had become the first man to be named executive director of the venerable League of Women Voters , a nonpartisan, voter education group probably best known for sponsoring Presidential debates. ''This is the perfect man-bites-dog story,'' said Mr. Thompson, who found himself answering questions this week from curious radio stations in San Antonio, Phoenix and St. Louis. The radio commentator Paul Harvey took note of his appointment, as did a Washington Post columnist who mentioned that Mr. Thompson ''won't be asked to type.''

headline.kicker: MAN IN THE NEWS: FRANKLIN R. CHANG-DIAZ
headline.main: A DREAMER IN SPACE

results.snippet: As a child in San Jose, Costa Rica, Franklin R. Chang-Diaz used to play inside an empty packing crate, pretending that it was a spaceship on its way to a distant star. Yesterday Dr. Chang realized part of his dream, riding into orbit aboard the...

byline.original: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

results.lead_paragraph: As a child in San Jose, Costa Rica, Franklin R. Chang-Diaz used to play inside an empty packing crate, pretending that it was a spaceship on its way to a distant star. Yesterday Dr. Chang realized part of his dream, riding into orbit aboard the shuttle Columbia as the first Hispanic American astronaut to fly in space. He came to the United States in 1968 with a one-way airplane ticket, $50 in his pocket, a suitcase, and a dream to fly in space. He had written to the rocket scientist Wernher von Braun asking advice on how to become an astronaut, and Dr. von Braun wrote back, telling the young man to come to America and study science. That was all the encouragement he needed. Relatives in Connecticut agreed to give him a home, and Franklin enrolled in public high school in Hartford. He nearly flunked out at first, but as his English improved so did his grades, and by graduation he had won a scholarship to the University of Connecticut.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS LAUNCH RCA SATELLITE

results.snippet: After weeks of frustration and a record seven postponements, the space shuttle Columbia soared into space this morning to begin a five-day scientific mission.   Within hours, the astronauts launched a $50 million communications satellite for the...

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: After weeks of frustration and a record seven postponements, the space shuttle Columbia soared into space this morning to begin a five-day scientific mission. Within hours, the astronauts launched a $50 million communications satellite for the RCA Corporation and prepared for experiments in materials science, astrophysics, and the life sciences. Later in the mission the crew is to make the first extensive observations from space of Halley's comet. The flight is the first of three consecutive flights that are to study the comet. Other nations have launched spacecraft toward the comet, but they are not yet in position.

headline.main: SPACE AGENCY TO END SHUTTLE MISSION A DAY EARLY

results.snippet: The astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia, no strangers to disappointment after its launching was postponed a record seven times, were ordered today to end their mission one day early by landing here Thursday.   Space agency officials, concerned...

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia, no strangers to disappointment after its launching was postponed a record seven times, were ordered today to end their mission one day early by landing here Thursday. Space agency officials, concerned about the ambitious schedule of 15 shuttle flights planned for this year, told the crew that a shortened, four-day mission would allow more flexibility in the face of impending bad weather, which could delay their return. ''We really appreciate your hard work,'' James Wetherbee of mission control in Houston radioed to the astronauts while telling them of the truncated mission. ''We'd like to let you stay a little bit longer, but we can't, so we'll bring you back one day early.''

headline.main: SPACE SHUTTLE, DETOURED TO CALIFORNIA BY WEATHER, LANDS SAFELY UNDER FOODLIGHTS

results.snippet: Guided by powerful floodlights, with the hint of dawn on a desert horizon, the space shuttle Columbia landed safely here today at 5:59 A.M., Pacific standard time.   The crew of seven astronauts had hoped to land in Florida, but they could not do...

byline.original: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Guided by powerful floodlights, with the hint of dawn on a desert horizon, the space shuttle Columbia landed safely here today at 5:59 A.M., Pacific standard time. The crew of seven astronauts had hoped to land in Florida, but they could not do so when the weather there took another turn for the worse after a landing was twice postponed. The mission began last Sunday. Landing conditions on the dry lake bed at the space agency's facility here were perfect. The desert was illuminated by six floodlights that gave out an estimated 4.8 trillion candlepower as the spaceship landed under a starry sky.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS ON HARD-LUCK FLIGHT FAILED TO GET A GLIMPSE OF COMET

results.snippet: Astronauts on the recent hard-luck flight of the space shuttle Columbia said today that a broken light intensifier kept them from taking pictures or even getting a glimpse of Halley's comet.   The astronauts, at their first news conference after...

byline.original: AP

results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts on the recent hard-luck flight of the space shuttle Columbia said today that a broken light intensifier kept them from taking pictures or even getting a glimpse of Halley's comet. The astronauts, at their first news conference after their trouble-plagued mission, said views of the comet were blotted out by the light of the Sun and the Moon. Even with binoculars, they said, they could not see the comet.

headline.main: TEACHER IS FOCUS OF SPACE MISSION

results.snippet: The flight of the first private citizen into space, scheduled to begin Sunday, has filled the Kennedy Space Center with crowds of teachers and tourists in what promises to be a public relations bonanza for the National Aeronautics and Space...

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The flight of the first private citizen into space, scheduled to begin Sunday, has filled the Kennedy Space Center with crowds of teachers and tourists in what promises to be a public relations bonanza for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Christa McAuliffe, a 37-year-old high school teacher from New Hampshire who was chosen in a space agency competition among more than 11,000 teachers to be one of the space shuttle Challenger's seven crew members, is set to begin her historic voyage Sunday at 9:36 A.M., equipment and weather permitting. Space agency officials said today that there was a 30 percent chance of rain Sunday morning.

headline.main: THE SEVEN WHO PERISHED IN THE EXPLOSION OF THE CHALLENGER

results.snippet: Christa McAuliffe Christa McAuliffe, a high-school social studies teacher from New Hampshire, was the winner of a nationwide competition to be the first private citizen to fly aboard a space shuttle. She was 37 years old.   Students always packed...
results.lead_paragraph: Christa McAuliffe Christa McAuliffe, a high-school social studies teacher from New Hampshire, was the winner of a nationwide competition to be the first private citizen to fly aboard a space shuttle. She was 37 years old. Students always packed Mrs. McAuliffe's classes at Concord High School because of her enthusiasm and ability to make dry subjects come alive. And so last July, when she was selected as the primary candidate to be the first teacher in space, broadcasting lessons to millions of people across the country, her students broke into applause.

headline.main: FOR THE FAMILIES, THE MOMENT OF DOOM

results.snippet: Bundled against the cold Florida morning, Ed and Grace Corrigan watched with pride and nervous excitement as the space shuttle Challenger, carrying their daughter, Christa McAuliffe, and six other astronauts, thundered off the launching pad here.  ...

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Bundled against the cold Florida morning, Ed and Grace Corrigan watched with pride and nervous excitement as the space shuttle Challenger, carrying their daughter, Christa McAuliffe, and six other astronauts, thundered off the launching pad here. Then, 74 seconds into the flight, their excitement turned to disbelief, then horror. There was a puff of smoke and a muffled clap, audible in a viewing grandstand where the Corrigans and relatives of the other astronauts were sitting. There was a moment when nobody was sure what had happened. People around them were still cheering, raising their thumbs in a signal of victory.

headline.main: THE SEVEN WHO PERISHED IN THE EXPLOSION OF THE CHALLENGER

results.snippet: Judith A. Resnik Dr. Judith A. Resnik, an Ohio-born electrical engineer, was one of three mission specialists on board the space shuttle. She was 36 years old.   An astronaut since 1978, Dr. Resnik became, in 1984, the second American woman to...
results.lead_paragraph: Judith A. Resnik Dr. Judith A. Resnik, an Ohio-born electrical engineer, was one of three mission specialists on board the space shuttle. She was 36 years old. An astronaut since 1978, Dr. Resnik became, in 1984, the second American woman to travel in space. The first was Dr. Sally K. Ride, who flew on a mission in 1983.

headline.main: DOUBTS AND CHANGES AFTER PAST DISASTERS

results.snippet: The inherent risks of exploring the universe have resulted in space-age accidents and deaths for astronauts from both the Soviet Union and the United States. The disasters have invariably slowed manned exploration as officials and engineers...
results.lead_paragraph: The inherent risks of exploring the universe have resulted in space-age accidents and deaths for astronauts from both the Soviet Union and the United States. The disasters have invariably slowed manned exploration as officials and engineers modified vehicles in an attempt to improve safety. The United States launched 16 manned missions before catastrophe struck. On Jan. 27, 1967, the crew of what would have been the first manned Apollo mission died when a fire broke out in their spacecraft as it sat on the launching pad. Within 15 seconds three astronauts were dead.

headline.main: THE SEVEN WHO PERISHED IN THE EXPLOSION OF THE CHALLENGER

results.snippet: Michael J. Smith Comdr. Michael J. Smith of the Navy, an astronaut since 1980, was pilot of the Challenger shuttle mission.
results.lead_paragraph: Michael J. Smith Comdr. Michael J. Smith of the Navy, an astronaut since 1980, was pilot of the Challenger shuttle mission.

headline.main: THE SEVEN WHO PERISHED IN THE EXPLOSION OF THE CHALLENGER

results.snippet: Ellison S. Onizuka Lieut. Col. Ellison S. Onizuka of the Air Force, an aerospace engineer, was a mission specialist on the shuttle. He was 39 years old.   Colonel Onizuka turned an elementary-school dream of being a space explorer into reality,...

byline.original: By United Press International

results.lead_paragraph: Ellison S. Onizuka Lieut. Col. Ellison S. Onizuka of the Air Force, an aerospace engineer, was a mission specialist on the shuttle. He was 39 years old. Colonel Onizuka turned an elementary-school dream of being a space explorer into reality, becoming an experienced Air Force flight test engineer who went on to fly aboard the space shuttle Discovery last year.

headline.main: SPECIAL SENSE OF TRAGEDY AND LOSS IN SCHOOLS

results.snippet: Because Christa McAuliffe was one of them, tens of thousands of teachers gathered their students around television sets in classrooms across the country yesterday morning.   The teachers beamed in anticipation of vicariously sharing in Mrs....

byline.original: By GENE I. MAEROFF

results.lead_paragraph: Because Christa McAuliffe was one of them, tens of thousands of teachers gathered their students around television sets in classrooms across the country yesterday morning. The teachers beamed in anticipation of vicariously sharing in Mrs. McAuliffe's achievement. They and their students looked forward to the lessons she was going to teach from the cramped confines of the space shuttle Challenger.

headline.main: BUSH FLIES TO SIDE OF CREW'S FAMILIES

results.snippet: Vice President Bush flew here this afternoon to try to comfort the families of the Challenger astronauts and, echoing President Reagan, urged the nation ''to press on'' in the face of a disaster.   Dispatched by the President in a gesture of...

byline.original: By GERALD M. BOYD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Vice President Bush flew here this afternoon to try to comfort the families of the Challenger astronauts and, echoing President Reagan, urged the nation ''to press on'' in the face of a disaster. Dispatched by the President in a gesture of sympathy, Mr. Bush made brief public remarks at the Kennedy Space Center and then went immediately to a private meeting with family members. The Vice President was joined by the two United States Senators who have flown in space, John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, who as an astronaut was the first American to orbit the earth, and Jake Garn, Republican of Utah. Also with Mr. Bush was Dr. William Graham, the acting Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

headline.main: AT MISSION CONTROL, SILENCE AND GRIEF FILL A DAY OF HORROR LONG DREADED

results.snippet: In the Mission Control room here today there was so little indication that anything was wrong with the shuttle that Stephen A. Nesbitt, the public affairs officer, routinely reported its position a minute and 15 seconds after launching as 7...

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: In the Mission Control room here today there was so little indication that anything was wrong with the shuttle that Stephen A. Nesbitt, the public affairs officer, routinely reported its position a minute and 15 seconds after launching as 7 nautical miles downrage. In fact, the craft had already exploded and was dropping into the Atlantic Ocean. There was a long pause, then Mr. Nesbitt, who had apparently been tracking the radar, continued: ''Flight controller here looking very carefully at situation. Obviously a major malfunction.''

headline.main: PRESIDENT EXPRESSES HIS SORROW AT THE ASTRONAUTS' DEATHS

results.snippet: Following is the transcript of President Reagan's statement to the nation from the Oval Office yesterday afternoon on the shuttle explosion, as recorded by The New York Times:   Following is the transcript of President Reagan's statement to the...
results.lead_paragraph: Following is the transcript of President Reagan's statement to the nation from the Oval Office yesterday afternoon on the shuttle explosion, as recorded by The New York Times: Following is the transcript of President Reagan's statement to the nation from the Oval Office yesterday afternoon on the shuttle explosion, as recorded by The New York Times: Ladies and gentlemen, I planned to speak to you tonight to report on the State of the Union, but the events of earlier today have led me to change those plans. Today is a day for mourning and remembering. Nancy and I are pained to the core by the tragedy of the shuttle Challenger. We know we share this pain with all of the people of our country. This is truly a national loss. Nineteen years ago, almost to the day, we lost three astronauts in a terrible accident on the ground, but we've never lost an astronaut in flight; we've never had a tragedy like this. And perhaps we've forgotten the courage it took for the crew of the shuttle but they, the Challenger seven, were aware of the dangers and overcame them and did their jobs brilliantly.

headline.main: THE SEVEN WHO PERISHED IN THE EXPLOSION OF THE CHALLENGER

results.snippet: Francis R. Scobee Francis R. (Dick) Scobee, a veteran test pilot who served as pilot on a Challenger shuttle mission in 1984, was the commander of the Challenger.   Mr. Scobee, who was 46 years old, was killed on his second space mission.   Mr....
results.lead_paragraph: Francis R. Scobee Francis R. (Dick) Scobee, a veteran test pilot who served as pilot on a Challenger shuttle mission in 1984, was the commander of the Challenger. Mr. Scobee, who was 46 years old, was killed on his second space mission. Mr. Scobee had logged more than 6,500 hours of flight time in 45 types of aircraft.

headline.main: AFTER THE SHOCK, A NEED TO SHARE GRIEF AND LOSS

results.snippet: The nation came together yesterday in a moment of disaster and loss. Wherever Americans were when they heard the news - at work, at school or at home - they shared their grief over the death of the seven astronauts, among them one who had captured...

byline.original: By SARA RIMER

results.lead_paragraph: The nation came together yesterday in a moment of disaster and loss. Wherever Americans were when they heard the news - at work, at school or at home - they shared their grief over the death of the seven astronauts, among them one who had captured their imaginations, Christa McAuliffe, the teacher from Concord, N.H., who was to have been the first ordinary citizen to go into space. Shortly before noon, when the first word of the explosion came, daily events seemed to stop as people awaited the details and asked the same questions: ''What happened? Are there any survivors?'' In offices, restaurants and stores, people gathered in front of television sets, mesmerized by the terrible scene of the shuttle exploding, a scene that would be replayed throughout the day and night. Children who had learned about Mrs. McAuliffe were watching in classrooms across the country.

headline.main: ACTING QUEENS CHIEF REGAREDE AS A MEDIATOR

results.snippet: During fractious Board of Estimate meetings, when positions have hardened and dialogue has ceased, Claire Shulman is known by her colleagues for breaking tension with a smile and then mending fences with a compromise.   ''Her great role is to be a...

byline.original: By JANE GROSS

results.lead_paragraph: During fractious Board of Estimate meetings, when positions have hardened and dialogue has ceased, Claire Shulman is known by her colleagues for breaking tension with a smile and then mending fences with a compromise. ''Her great role is to be a mediator,'' said Rosemary Ginty, the director of intergovernmental relations for Mayor Koch, who has served alongside Mrs. Shulman on the Board of Estimate since 1976. ''It isn't as if she pokes her nose in, but she has the ability to see two sides of an issue, even when she's on one side.''

headline.main: TROUBLING QUESTIONS

results.snippet: The explosion of the space shuttle Challenger today will disrupt what space officials had proclaimed as ''the most important year since the space age began.'' It will also raise troubling questions about the long-term future of the manned space...

byline.original: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The explosion of the space shuttle Challenger today will disrupt what space officials had proclaimed as ''the most important year since the space age began.'' It will also raise troubling questions about the long-term future of the manned space program, according to a variety of space analysts. The accident will inevitably put a big crimp in the space agency's plans to launch 15 shuttle missions this year, far more than ever before. The most immediate impact will be postponement of future shuttle activities until a formal investigation is concluded and any needed corrective action is completed. That delay could force postponement of long-awaited missions to the sun and to Jupiter, as well as the launching of a huge space telescope later this year.

headline.main: THE SEVEN WHO PERISHED IN THE EXPLOSION OF THE CHALLENGER

results.snippet: Ronald E. McNair Dr. Ronald Erwin McNair, a physicist who became an astronaut in 1978, was the shuttle crew member who was to have launched a science platform to observe Halley's comet.   The second black American to leave the earth on a shuttle...
results.lead_paragraph: Ronald E. McNair Dr. Ronald Erwin McNair, a physicist who became an astronaut in 1978, was the shuttle crew member who was to have launched a science platform to observe Halley's comet. The second black American to leave the earth on a shuttle mission, Dr. McNair was on the crew of the Challenger in 1984 on the 10th shuttle flight. The first black American to fly in space was Lieut. Col. Guion S. Bluford Jr. of the Air Force, in September 1983.

headline.main: The Death of a School Teacher

results.snippet: NASA's achievement was to make the space shuttle seem routine. It never really was. The complexity of the machinery and its massive computer program led to frequent launch delays. A serious mishap nearly marred a shuttle flight last July when the...
results.lead_paragraph: NASA's achievement was to make the space shuttle seem routine. It never really was. The complexity of the machinery and its massive computer program led to frequent launch delays. A serious mishap nearly marred a shuttle flight last July when the main engine failed and the craft barely reached orbit. Yesterday, the routine disintegrated into catastrophe.

headline.main: REFLECTING ON LOSS: WELLING OF TEARS, A DESIRE TO PRESS ON

results.snippet: The explosion yesterday of an American shuttle shortly after liftoff, with the death of its crew of seven people, stunned and deeply saddened much of the nation. Many of those who reflected on the disaster tell how it appeared from their...
results.lead_paragraph: The explosion yesterday of an American shuttle shortly after liftoff, with the death of its crew of seven people, stunned and deeply saddened much of the nation. Many of those who reflected on the disaster tell how it appeared from their perspective, as religious leaders, writers, students, psychiatrists, educators, scientists and test pilots. Daniel J. Boorstin The Librarian of Congress I have a terrible feeling of sadness, I want to weep. In the long run, this shows us that the best things in life are not free. It makes us more grateful to the people who have been taking these risks all along without our knowing it. I hope this won't stop the space program, I don't think it will. Sir Francis Drake, Magellan, countless other great explorers lost their lives; this happens in any great adventure. It's sad it has to happen but somebody has to take these chances if we're to do things that have never been done before.

headline.main: THE NETWORKS' COVERAGE OF THE SHUTTLE TRAGEDY

results.snippet: WITHIN minutes of the time television began reporting on the space shuttle tragedy yesterday, two questions dominated the coverage. The first, obviously, was, what happened? The second was, what did it mean? Speculation and reporting mingled. This...

byline.original: By JOHN CORRY

results.lead_paragraph: WITHIN minutes of the time television began reporting on the space shuttle tragedy yesterday, two questions dominated the coverage. The first, obviously, was, what happened? The second was, what did it mean? Speculation and reporting mingled. This wasn't necessarily improper or unfair; it was more that television, once again, was speeding up our thinking. West Coast viewers of NBC saw the tragedy when it happened at 11:38 A.M., Eastern time; John Palmer reported, with live film, on ''Today.'' The Cable News Network, which regularly covers space missions, also had live coverage. Then, within minutes, CBS and ABC had the story. By noon, anchormen from all three networks were on the air.

headline.main: THE MOURNING FAMILIES RETURN HOME

results.snippet: For seven long and mournful minutes this morning church bells pealed all over the city of Houston, the nation's space capital, from which seven space travelers began a fateful journey that ended Tuesday when the space shuttle Challenger exploded...

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: For seven long and mournful minutes this morning church bells pealed all over the city of Houston, the nation's space capital, from which seven space travelers began a fateful journey that ended Tuesday when the space shuttle Challenger exploded over the Atlantic. Nowhere was the mourning, the sense of helpless grief, greater than in the communities that have sprung up around the sprawling Johnson Space Center, 25 miles south of downtown Houston, where the dead astronauts were just neighbors, fellow churchgoers, people who mowed their lawns on Saturdays. With a walkie-talkie in hand, Stan Avent was standing guard this afternoon in front of the neat, tan-brick home in Clear Lake City where his neighbor, Lieut. Col. Ellison S. Onizuka of the Air Force, had lived. ''What can I say?'' asked Mr. Avent, who, like Colonel Onizuka, was an employee of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ''I was a friend and I've lost a close friend. I'm grieving like everybody else.''

headline.kicker: THE SHUTTLE INQUIRY: SEARCH FOR ALTERNATIVES
headline.main: EUROPEANS EXPECT DELAYED PROJECTS

results.snippet: The explosion of the space shuttle Challenger is expected to have far-reaching effects on the pace and perhaps the future of European space projects, government and industry officials in several European countries said today.   The French-led...

byline.original: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The explosion of the space shuttle Challenger is expected to have far-reaching effects on the pace and perhaps the future of European space projects, government and industry officials in several European countries said today. The French-led Ariane satellite launcher has emerged in recent years as a serious competitor to the shuttle in the lucrative business of putting commercial satellites into space. France is also spearheading efforts to develop a European space shuttle.

headline.kicker: THE SHUTTLE INQUIRY: THE TOIL IN HUMAN TERMS
headline.main: IN CONCORD, MCAULIFFE'S NEIGHBORS MOURN LOSS OF A 'SHING EXAMPLE'

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: ST JOHN THE EVANGELIST ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH

results.snippet: Faith Hughes remembered the time last year when she and the other seniors at the Concord High School gave Christa McAuliffe a parachute, as a joke and a memento to mark her becoming a finalist in the Teacher in Space program.   She said she thought...

byline.original: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Faith Hughes remembered the time last year when she and the other seniors at the Concord High School gave Christa McAuliffe a parachute, as a joke and a memento to mark her becoming a finalist in the Teacher in Space program. She said she thought of the gift on Tuesday when she saw a parachute emerge from the sky just after the space shuttle Challenger exploded. But the parachute seen on television did not save Mrs. McAuliffe or her colleagues on the shuttle; it had apparently been attached to one of the booster rockets. Virginia Timmons remembered how pleasant it was when Mrs. McAuliffe, her next-door neighbor, came over for coffee on the afternoon of New Year's Eve, and she and other women from the neighborhood talked about children, homes and cross-country skiing.

headline.main: Handling Bad News

results.snippet: In June 1969, White House speechwriters were crafting phrases President Nixon might use in congratulating the first men to land on the moon. We assumed a safe return, but were drawn up short by a call from Frank Borman, the astronaut assigned by...

byline.original: By William Safire

results.lead_paragraph: In June 1969, White House speechwriters were crafting phrases President Nixon might use in congratulating the first men to land on the moon. We assumed a safe return, but were drawn up short by a call from Frank Borman, the astronaut assigned by NASA to be White House liaison. ''You want to be thinking of some alternative posture for the President,'' said the astronaut, ''in the event of mishaps on Apollo XI.'' When I did not immediately catch his drift, he added ''like what to do for the widows.''

headline.main: HUGE AUDIENCE FOR SHUTTLE COVERAGE

results.snippet: Viewers hungry for information about the space-shuttle disaster caused a sharp increase in network news ratings Tuesday night.   Yesterday, the networks were divided on how to handle follow-up coverage.   NBC News interrupted regular daytime...
results.lead_paragraph: Viewers hungry for information about the space-shuttle disaster caused a sharp increase in network news ratings Tuesday night. Yesterday, the networks were divided on how to handle follow-up coverage. NBC News interrupted regular daytime programming for live coverage of two NASA news conferences, and ABC News provided live coverage of one of them.

headline.kicker: THE SHUTTLE INQUIRY: REACTION HERE AND ABROAD
headline.main: GORBACHEV EXPRESSES HIS CONDOLENCES

results.snippet: Mikhail S. Gorbachev and officials of the Soviet space program sent condolences over the shuttle disaster today, while Muscovites voiced incredulity and shock at the explosion.   The blast was shown on nationwide Soviet television Tuesday and in...

byline.original: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Mikhail S. Gorbachev and officials of the Soviet space program sent condolences over the shuttle disaster today, while Muscovites voiced incredulity and shock at the explosion. The blast was shown on nationwide Soviet television Tuesday and in greater detail today. Some Russians who watched seemed particularly horrified by the fact that two women were among the victims, and one woman dabbed at her tears as the youthful astronauts were shown smiling, headed for their mission. Some Muscovites reported disbelief among their acquaintances that such a disaster could strike an American spaceship. ''Russians have been raised with a strong faith in American technology, and people couldn't believe that this could happen,'' said one middle-aged man. ''They were surprised to learn that there was no ejection mechanism.''

headline.kicker: THE SHUTTLE INQUIRY: SEARCH FOR ALTERNATIVESISSUE AND DEBATE
headline.main: SHOULD U.S. CONTINUE TO SEND PEOPLE INTO SPACE?

results.snippet: The explosion of the space shuttle Challenger Tuesday is raising anew the question of whether it is worth the risk and the expense for the United States to send people into space.   The question has arisen time and again since the space age began...

byline.original: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The explosion of the space shuttle Challenger Tuesday is raising anew the question of whether it is worth the risk and the expense for the United States to send people into space. The question has arisen time and again since the space age began in the 1950's, and while space travel has become ever more sophisticated, the arguments about humans versus machines in space have remained basically the same. The position held by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and a succession of American Presidents is that mankind must expand the horizons of knowledge and that no machines will ever be invented that can make judgments as well as human beings. On the other side, some scientists and politicians hold that remote-control robots and cameras can perform almost every identifiable mission in space at a far lower cost in terms of money and human lives. Both sides agree on one point: Had it not been for the drama provided by men in space - from the first flights of Yuri A. Gagarin and Alan B. Shepard Jr. through the landing on the moon in 1969 and the shuttle flights of recent years - Congress and the American people would have been less enthusiastic about providing the backing for the space program.

headline.main: SHUTTLE'S BUILDERS HAVE VARYING STAKES IN PROGRAM'S FUTURE

results.snippet: Many of the leading names in the United States aerospace industry are key contractors in the space shuttle program. As in other major aerospace projects, however, their dependence on the program is not as great as their huge National Aeronautics...
results.lead_paragraph: Many of the leading names in the United States aerospace industry are key contractors in the space shuttle program. As in other major aerospace projects, however, their dependence on the program is not as great as their huge National Aeronautics and Space Administration contracts might suggest because a great deal of the work is passed to hundreds of subcontractors. Nevertheless, all the industry giants involved in the project were shaken, financially as well as emotionally, by the explosion of the Challenger. A day after the disaster, they declined to comment on their theories about the accident's possible causes. But they said they all expect to participate in NASA's investigation.

headline.kicker: THE SHUTTLE INQUIRY: REACTION HERE AND ABROAD
headline.main: 'DEEP SORROW IN MY SOUL,' POPE SAYS

results.snippet: Pope John Paul II said today that the deaths of seven Americans on the space shuttle Challenger had ''provoked deep sorrow in my soul.''   Speaking at his weekly general audience in the Vatican, the Pope asked his audience of several thousand to...

byline.original: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Pope John Paul II said today that the deaths of seven Americans on the space shuttle Challenger had ''provoked deep sorrow in my soul.'' Speaking at his weekly general audience in the Vatican, the Pope asked his audience of several thousand to pray with him for those who died, saying, ''I lift up to God a fervent prayer so that he accepts in his embrace the souls of these courageous pioneers in progress of science and of man.'' The Pope also spoke of his ''heartfelt participation in the torment'' the astronauts' families were suffering.

headline.kicker: THE SHUTTLE INQUIRY: REACTION HERE AND ABROAD
headline.main: ON FLORIDA COAST, A SOMBER MOOD AND A SENSE OF THE INEVITABLE

results.snippet: For more than 20 years the bartenders at Bernard's Surf have poured a free drink for anyone in the lounge when a space flight went up. But on Tuesday there were no takers.   ''I offered, but no one felt like it,'' said Rusty Fischer, the owner of...

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: For more than 20 years the bartenders at Bernard's Surf have poured a free drink for anyone in the lounge when a space flight went up. But on Tuesday there were no takers. ''I offered, but no one felt like it,'' said Rusty Fischer, the owner of the restaurant, which since the early 1960's has been a popular hangout for astronauts and employees of the space program. ''It was a shock. Like a death in the family.''

headline.main: East Harlem Remembers

results.snippet: Dr. Ronald E. McNair, the astronaut who was the second black American to leave the earth on a shuttle mission, did not live in East Harlem in Manhattan, but in the Clear Lake area near Houston.   However, his father, Carl McNair, operated an...

byline.original: By Susan Heller Anderson and David Bird

results.lead_paragraph: Dr. Ronald E. McNair, the astronaut who was the second black American to leave the earth on a shuttle mission, did not live in East Harlem in Manhattan, but in the Clear Lake area near Houston. However, his father, Carl McNair, operated an automobile-body shop on East 122d Street for 22 years, and the neighborhood had proudly embraced his son as one of their own.

headline.main: NASA'S INQUIRY BEGINS: STATUS IS NOT DISCLOSED

results.snippet: While major portions of the space shuttle Challenger were recovered from the Atlantic Ocean today, investigators met to study the meager evidence relating to the explosion that destroyed the spaceship and its crew of seven.   The National...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: While major portions of the space shuttle Challenger were recovered from the Atlantic Ocean today, investigators met to study the meager evidence relating to the explosion that destroyed the spaceship and its crew of seven. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration refused to permit any of its officials to discuss the expanding investigation into the disaster Tuesday or to speculate on the possible causes of the worst accident in the nation's 25 years of spacefaring. In a brief statement tonight, the space agency said the National Transportation Safety Board was joining the investigation, providing its expertise in reconstructing airplane accidents and their causes. The NASA panel met all day at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida and was to resume its work Friday at the Johnson Space Center here.
